title: What will happen when we are unable to appear in court? Is this something we can go to jail for?
question: Obtained medical insurance. Had gallbladder removed. Bill was $170,000.00 all but $1600.00 has been paid. For the past year 3 collections places have called me daily. I was just served a civil filing by the hospitals lawyer. Court is an hour and a half drive and we have no car. We are poor and pay for the insurance as is the law now and have paid what we could.
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Bankruptcy homestead exemption,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Real estate and bankruptcy,Real estate,Social security,Lawsuits and disputes,Civil rights,Fees,Default judgment
answers: If you have a job and/or equity in your home, you may wish to consider filing a Bankruptcy, but not if your debt totals only $1,600. If you have additional debt, then bankruptcy may be a way to wipe the slate clean, to take your "fresh start". If you are not working, and do not have too many assets, then, as these other attorneys have suggested, you may be "judgment-proof", which means that though the creditor gets a judgment against you, there is no way for them to collect any money from you. Please notice all of the "ifs". We need more information to really advise you, so please do not rely on any of our comments. You should take advantage of a free consultation with a bankruptcy attorney near your home who also understands consumer collection laws. Your creditors may be too aggressive, and thus may be liable for violating the Unfair Debt Collection Practices Act and its California version, as well. If so, your creditors would pay any attorney fees associated with suing them for violating your rights. You may also be a good candidate for a "cease and desist letter", which makes it illegal for your collectors to continue contacting you and sending you letters. Their only option is to sue you after receiving such a letter, and often they will not do so if they are convinced you are judgment-proof. However, as before, you need a competent local attorney to help you with these considerations. Use the Avvo "Find a lawyer" tab, above, or contact an attorney on the membership list of the National Assn. of Consumer Bankruptcy Attorneys (NACBA) or the National Assn. of Consumer Attorneys (NACA). Jus try to find one who understands Bankruptcy and non-Bankruptcy options, including suing your collectors. God Bless You!! Try to have a Merry Christmas! Don't allow these collection gnomes to get you down during this happy season!

If you don't appear in court, the collection agencies will take a default judgment against you. Then they will have to collect on the loan but you sound judgment proof to me. They can't take your social security and you have a $175,000 homestead exemption on your home. If you write this in a letter, they may back off.

No, you will not go to jail for not participating in a civil lawsuit. The creditor will get a judgment against you for what is still due. When they try to collect it, they will realize that you are "judgment proof" meaning that you have no non-exempt assets, no real estate equity, no job/wages, no money in your bank account, no expensive cars, etc.
